Exercise 3.7.1

Complete the proof of Theorem 3.7.1. Compare this theorem with Example 1.2.10, and explain why this example does not contradict the theorem.

Theorem (3.7.1)

Let [a,b]\br{a, b}[a,b] be an interval, and for every integer n≥1n \geq 1n≥1, let fn ⁣:[a,b]→Rf_n\colon \br{a, b} \to \Rfn​:[a,b]→R be a differentiable function whose derivative fn′ ⁣:[a,b]→Rf_n'\colon \br{a, b} \to \Rfn′​:[a,b]→R is continuous.

Suppose that the derivatives fn′f_n'fn′​ converge uniformly to a function g ⁣:[a,b]→Rg\colon \br{a, b} \to \Rg:[a,b]→R. Suppose also that there exists a point x0x_0x0​ such that the limit lim⁡n→∞fn(x0)\lim_{n \to \infty} f_n(x_0)limn→∞​fn​(x0​) exists.

Then the functions fnf_nfn​ converge uniformly to a differentiable function fff, and the derivative of fff equals ggg.
Solution.

To complete the proof, it remains to show that fn→ff_n \to ffn​→f uniformly and that fff is differentiable with f′=gf' = gf′=g, where

f(x)≔L−∫[a,x0]g+∫[a,x]g,L≔lim⁡n→∞fn(x0).f\p{x} \coloneqq L - \int_{\br{a, x_0}} g + \int_{\br{a, x}} g, \quad L \coloneqq \lim_{n\to\infty} f_n\p{x_0}.f(x):=L−∫[a,x0​]​g+∫[a,x]​g,L:=n→∞lim​fn​(x0​).

Since fn′f_n'fn′​ is continuous, it is automatically Riemann integrable. Thus, we may apply the fundamental theorem of calculus to write

fn(x)=fn(x0)−∫[a,x0]fn′+∫[a,x]fn′f_n\p{x} = f_n\p{x_0} - \int_{\br{a, x_0}} f_n' + \int_{\br{a, x}} f_n'fn​(x)=fn​(x0​)−∫[a,x0​]​fn′​+∫[a,x]​fn′​

for any x∈[a,b]x \in \br{a, b}x∈[a,b]. Thus, for any x∈[a,b]x \in \br{a, b}x∈[a,b], we have by the triangle inequality

∣fn(x)−f(x)∣=∣fn(x0)−∫[a,x0]fn′+∫[a,x]fn′−(L−∫[a,x0]g+∫[a,x]g)∣≤∣fn(x0)−L∣+∫[a,x0]∣fn′−g∣+∫[a,x]∣fn′−g∣≤∣fn(x0)−L∣+2(b−a)∥fn′−g∥∞.\begin{aligned} \abs{f_n\p{x} - f\p{x}} &= \abs{f_n\p{x_0} - \int_{\br{a, x_0}} f_n' + \int_{\br{a, x}} f_n' - \p{L - \int_{\br{a, x_0}} g + \int_{\br{a, x}} g}} \\ &\leq \abs{f_n\p{x_0} - L} + \int_{\br{a, x_0}} \abs{f_n' - g} + \int_{\br{a, x}} \abs{f_n' - g} \\ &\leq \abs{f_n\p{x_0} - L} + 2\p{b - a} \norm{f_n' - g}_\infty. \end{aligned}∣fn​(x)−f(x)∣​=∣∣​fn​(x0​)−∫[a,x0​]​fn′​+∫[a,x]​fn′​−(L−∫[a,x0​]​g+∫[a,x]​g)∣∣​≤∣fn​(x0​)−L∣+∫[a,x0​]​∣fn′​−g∣+∫[a,x]​∣fn′​−g∣≤∣fn​(x0​)−L∣+2(b−a)∥fn′​−g∥∞​.​

Since xxx was arbitrary, we immediately get

∥fn−f∥∞≤∣fn(x0)−L∣+2(b−a)∥fn′−g∥∞.\norm{f_n - f}_\infty \leq \abs{f_n\p{x_0} - L} + 2\p{b - a} \norm{f_n' - g}_\infty.∥fn​−f∥∞​≤∣fn​(x0​)−L∣+2(b−a)∥fn′​−g∥∞​.

∣fn(x0)−L∣→0\abs{f_n\p{x_0} - L} \to 0∣fn​(x0​)−L∣→0 by definition of LLL and ∥fn′−g∥∞→0\norm{f_n' - g}_\infty \to 0∥fn′​−g∥∞​→0 since fn′→gf_n' \to gfn′​→g uniformly. Thus, by the squeeze theorem, ∥fn−f∥∞→0\norm{f_n - f}_\infty \to 0∥fn​−f∥∞​→0, i.e., fn→ff_n \to ffn​→f uniformly.

Finally, notice that ggg is continuous since it is the uniform limit of continuous functions. Thus, the fundamental theorem of calculus implies that fff is differentiable with f′=gf' = gf′=g.

Proposition (4.2.6)

Let EEE be a subset of R\RR, let aaa be an interior point of EEE, and let fff be a function which is real analytic at aaa, thus there is an r>0r > 0r>0 for which we have the power series expansion

f(x)=∑n=0∞cn(x−a)nf\p{x} = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n \p{x - a}^nf(x)=n=0∑∞​cn​(x−a)n

for all x∈(a−r,a+r)x \in \p{a - r, a + r}x∈(a−r,a+r). Then for every k≥0k \geq 0k≥0, the function fff is kkk-times differentiable on (a−r,a+r)\p{a - r, a + r}(a−r,a+r), and for each k≥0k \geq 0k≥0, the kkk-th derivative is given by

for all x∈(a−r,a+r)x \in \p{a - r, a + r}x∈(a−r,a+r).
Theorem (4.1.6)

Let ∑n=0∞cn(x−a)n\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n \p{x - a}^n∑n=0∞​cn​(x−a)n be a formal power series, and let RRR be its radius of convergence.

  1. (Divergence outside of the radius of convergence) If x∈Rx \in \Rx∈R is such that ∣x−a∣>R\abs{x - a} > R∣x−a∣>R, then the series ∑n=0∞cn(x−a)n\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n \p{x - a}^n∑n=0∞​cn​(x−a)n is divergent for that value of xxx.

  2. (Convergence inside the radius of convergence) If x∈Rx \in \Rx∈R is such that ∣x−a∣<R\abs{x - a} < R∣x−a∣<R, then the series ∑n=0∞cn(x−a)n\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n \p{x - a}^n∑n=0∞​cn​(x−a)n is absolutely convergent for that value of xxx.

  3. (Uniform convergence on compact sets) For any 0<r<R0 < r < R0<r<R, the series ∑n=0∞cn(x−a)n\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n \p{x - a}^n∑n=0∞​cn​(x−a)n converges uniformly to fff on the compact interval [a−r,a+r]\br{a - r, a + r}[a−r,a+r]. In particular, fff is continuous on (a−R,a+R)\p{a - R, a + R}(a−R,a+R).

  4. (Differentiation of power series) The function fff is differentiable on (a−R,a+R)\p{a - R, a + R}(a−R,a+R), and for any 0<r<R0 < r < R0<r<R, the series ∑n=1∞ncn(x−a)n−1\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} n c_n \p{x - a}^{n - 1}∑n=1∞​ncn​(x−a)n−1 converges uniformly to f′f'f′ on the interval [a−r,a+r]\br{a - r, a + r}[a−r,a+r].

  5. (Integration of power series) For any closed interval [y,z]\br{y, z}[y,z] contained in (a−R,a+R)\p{a - R, a + R}(a−R,a+R), we have

∫[y,z]f(x) dx=∑n=0∞cn(z−a)n+1−(y−a)n+1n+1.\int_{\br{y, z}} f(x) \, dx = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n \frac{\p{z - a}^{n+1} - \p{y - a}^{n+1}}{n+1}.∫[y,z]​f(x)dx=n=0∑∞​cn​n+1(z−a)n+1−(y−a)n+1​.

For parts (iii)-(iv) we assume that R>0R > 0R>0 (i.e., the series converges at at least one other point than x=ax = ax=a). Let f ⁣:(a−R,a+R)→Rf\colon \p{a - R, a + R} \to \Rf:(a−R,a+R)→R be the function f(x)≔∑n=0∞cn(x−a)nf\p{x} \coloneqq \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n \p{x - a}^nf(x):=∑n=0∞​cn​(x−a)n; this function is guaranteed to exist by part (b).
Solution.

We will prove the following statement for all k≥0k \geq 0k≥0 by induction:

P(k)=[f(k)(x)=∑n=0∞cn+k(n+k)!n!(x−a)n for x∈(a−r,a+r)].P\p{k} = \br{f^{\p{k}}\p{x} = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_{n+k} \frac{\p{n+k}!}{n!} \p{x - a}^n \text{ for } x \in \p{a - r, a + r}}.P(k)=[f(k)(x)=n=0∑∞​cn+k​n!(n+k)!​(x−a)n for x∈(a−r,a+r)].

Base case: k=0k = 0k=0

In this case, P(0)P\p{0}P(0) is the statement

f(0)(x)=∑n=0∞cn(x−a)n for x∈(a−r,a+r),f^{\p{0}}\p{x} = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n \p{x - a}^n \text{ for } x \in \p{a - r, a + r},f(0)(x)=n=0∑∞​cn​(x−a)n for x∈(a−r,a+r),

which holds by assumption.

Inductive step:

Suppose P(k)P\p{k}P(k) holds for some k≥0k \geq 0k≥0. In particular, f(k)f^{\p{k}}f(k) is real analytic with positive radius of convergence (it's at least rrr), so by Theorem 4.1.6(iv),

f(k+1)(x)=∑n=1∞ncn+k(n+k)!n!(x−a)n−1 for x∈(a−r,a+r).f^{\p{k+1}}\p{x} = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} nc_{n+k} \frac{\p{n+k}!}{n!} \p{x - a}^{n-1} \text{ for } x \in \p{a - r, a + r}.f(k+1)(x)=n=1∑∞​ncn+k​n!(n+k)!​(x−a)n−1 for x∈(a−r,a+r).

Reindexing by replacing n→n+1n \to n + 1n→n+1 (which we can do since nnn is just a dummy variable in the sum), we see

f(k+1)(x)=∑n=0∞(n+1)cn+k+1(n+k+1)!(n+1)!(x−a)n=∑n=0∞cn+k+1(n+k+1)!n!(x−a)n\begin{aligned} f^{\p{k+1}}\p{x} &= \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \p{n+1}c_{n+k+1} \frac{\p{n+k+1}!}{\p{n+1}!} \p{x - a}^n \\ &= \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_{n+k+1} \frac{\p{n+k+1}!}{n!} \p{x - a}^n \end{aligned}f(k+1)(x)​=n=0∑∞​(n+1)cn+k+1​(n+1)!(n+k+1)!​(x−a)n=n=0∑∞​cn+k+1​n!(n+k+1)!​(x−a)n​

for x∈(a−r,a+r)x \in \p{a - r, a + r}x∈(a−r,a+r). Thus, P(k+1)P\p{k+1}P(k+1) holds are we are done.
